nodes.name: Underfunding of high-impact early-stage longtermist projects
aliases: Funding gap for AI safety and biosecurity seed projects
Insufficient capital for early-stage x-risk work
nodes.description: The risk that critical early-stage research and initiatives aimed at reducing global catastrophic risks (e.g. AI safety, biosecurity) are not carried out because the Long-Term Future Fund lacks sufficient resources.
nodes.node_rationale: ‘Background on the LTFF’ emphasises the need to fund small, high-impact projects to improve humanity’s long-term trajectory.

nodes.name: Limited donation inflow relative to high-quality grant applications
nodes.description: The number and quality of applications outstrip available capital, leading to a higher grantmaking bar.
nodes.node_rationale: Mentioned in several sections (e.g. fundraising appeal) as the primary operational bottleneck.

nodes.name: Donor misunderstanding of marginal grant impact in LTFF context
nodes.description: Potential donors often assume their money funds the ‘average’ LTFF grant instead of the lower-scoring marginal grants that would actually be enabled.
nodes.node_rationale: Stated in the motivation for transparency: donors need to understand marginal impact.

nodes.name: Transparency about marginal grant opportunities increases donor willingness to give
nodes.description: Providing clear information on what additional donations would purchase can correct misconceptions and motivate donations.
nodes.node_rationale: Authors explicitly state that showing marginal projects should ‘help improve the quality of thinking and discussions about charities’ and attract funds.

nodes.name: Provide representative fictional grant examples at funding tiers
nodes.description: A communication strategy of listing hypothetical but realistic grants at different fundraising levels to concretise marginal impact.
nodes.node_rationale: Described under ‘Grant tiers’ as the mechanism chosen to convey transparency.

nodes.name: Publication of LTFF blog post with tiered grant examples and 2:1 matching details
nodes.description: The concrete act of releasing the post that lists the tiers and advertises Open Phil’s 2:1 match.
nodes.node_rationale: The post itself is the mechanism realising the design rationale.

nodes.name: LTFF historical application and threshold data 2022-2023
nodes.description: Empirical record of 878 applications, 263 grants (~$9.1 M) and threshold changes (2.0→2.9), evidencing both demand and adaptive policy.
nodes.node_rationale: Cited in ‘Background’ and ‘Methodology’ sections to justify transparency and adaptive threshold decisions.

nodes.name: Publish donor-facing blog post detailing tiered fictional grants and 2:1 matching appeal
nodes.description: Release and publicise the tiered-grant blog post, explicitly highlighting Open Philanthropy’s 2:1 donation match to stimulate additional giving.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Public communication occurs after model and policy decisions; corresponds to Deployment/External outreach section of post.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Already operational—post is live and being used in real fundraising.
nodes.node_rationale: Primary action the paper urges readers to support in order to close the funding gap.

nodes.name: Misallocation of LTFF funds due to static grant funding thresholds
aliases: Inefficient grant allocation from fixed bar
nodes.description: If the grantmaking bar does not adjust to donation levels, available funds may be spent on lower-value projects or withheld unnecessarily.
nodes.node_rationale: Discussed in ‘Appendix A: Donation smoothing’ and throughout fundraising rationale.

nodes.name: Variable donation levels create mismatch between funding bar and available resources
nodes.description: Fluctuating inflows mean a fixed threshold either overspends in low-donation periods or under-spends in high-donation periods.
nodes.node_rationale: Explicitly noted when authors explain why threshold rose to 2.9 and would fall with more funds.

nodes.name: Adaptive funding threshold maintains grant cost-effectiveness
nodes.description: Linking the threshold to available funds ensures that only grants above a certain cost-effectiveness score are funded.
nodes.node_rationale: Rationale given in ‘Methodology’ and ‘Grant tiers’ when discussing how the bar shifts.

nodes.name: Set grant scoring threshold relative to available budget
nodes.description: Operational principle: calculate how many high-scoring grants can be afforded and set the score cut-off accordingly.
nodes.node_rationale: Outlined in ‘Methodology for this analysis’ describing how threshold was computed.

nodes.name: Adjustment of grant scoring threshold (e.g., 2.9) based on reserves
nodes.description: Concrete implementation: raising the funding bar from 2.5 to 2.9 in response to donation shortfalls and application surge.
nodes.node_rationale: Specific example given in ‘Methodology’ of implementing the adaptive threshold policy.

nodes.name: Implement dynamic grant scoring threshold policy
nodes.description: Continuously update the approval score threshold so total grants approximately match available funds, preserving cost-effectiveness across donation fluctuations.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Internal operational process executed during grantmaking (pre-deployment of funds).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Already in practical use, with documented threshold changes over multiple rounds.
nodes.node_rationale: Key policy action intended to prevent inefficient allocation when donations vary.
